text:
Sediment provenances and drainage evolution of the
Neogene Amazonian foreland basin
Martin Roddaz *, Je´roˆme Viers, Ste´phane Brusset, Patrice Baby, Ge´rard He´rail
LMTG UMR 5563-14 Avenue Edouard Belin, 31400 Toulouse, France

Received 28 January 2005; received in revised form 19 July 2005; accepted 11 August 2005
Available online 22 September 2005
Editor: K. Farley

During the Middle–Late Miocene, tidal sedimentation was the rule in the Amazon foreland basin. The Amazon foreland
basin became emerged in the Late Miocene–Pliocene times. In this study, trace element chemistry (n =104) and Nd–Sr isotopic
systematic (n =30) are used to constrain the provenance of the Miocene tidal sediments and of the Late Miocene–Pliocene
fluvial sediments. Neogene Amazonian foreland basin sediments are the result of a mixing between Andean andesitic volcanic
rocks and cratonic shield rocks. The south Amazonian foreland basin (SAFB) sediments are the result of long-term weathering,
recycling, and erosion of the Brazilian shield and Andean Paleozoic/Mesozoic rocks also Brazilian shield in provenance.
Compared with north Amazonian foreland basin (NAFB) sediments, SAFB sediments are more felsic. NAFB sediments have 3
distinct signatures: i) an upper crust signature with trace element characteristics similar to PAAS and UCC and with eNd(0)
values between 8 and 11.9; ii) an arc andesitic rock signature with high Cr/Th ratios, low Eu anomalies, low Th/Sc ratios
and eNd(0) values between 3 and 5; and iii) a cratonic signature with high Eu anomalies and Zr/Sc ratios and with a very
low eNd(0) value (15.5). Our data indicate that most of the basic detritus came from the Ecuadorian Andes. In the distal part
of the NAFB, the successive uplifts of the Iquitos forebulge were responsible for Late Miocene to Pliocene divide between
Andean and cratonic drainage systems. The modern bAmazon RiverQ drainage network is no younger than the Pliocene.
D 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Neogene; Amazonian foreland basin; trace elements geochemistry; Nd–Sr isotopes; provenance; drainage network

The Amazon Basin is the worldTs largest Cenozoic
fluvial basin with an actual drainage area of 5.8106

* Corresponding author. Fax: +33 5 61 33 26 50.
E-mail address: mroddaz@lmtg.obs-mip.fr (M. Roddaz).

0012-821X/$ - see front matter D 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
doi:10.1016/j.epsl.2005.08.007

km2 and a depositional area of approximately 2.5–
3106 km2. The Amazon rainforest, with an area of
about 5.6106 km2, is the largest rainforest ecosys-
tem, representing nearly 50% of the total tropical
rainforest area on Earth. The Amazon rainforest
plays a significant role in global climate, the carbon
cycle and biodiversity. To understand the modern
Amazon rainforest ecosystem, and how it may

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
58

respond to future changes, paleoenvironmental and
paleoecological studies are crucial. Tropical rainfor-
ests are well known for their high biodiversity [1,2],
yet it is unclear which conditions in the past have
permitted the evolution as well as conservation of
such high degree of diversity. Historically, the high
biodiversity has been ascribed to the stability of the
rainforest ecosystem during the Quaternary. However,
gradually, it became clear that at least parts of the
tropical forest also had experienced a dynamic history
as a result of precipitation change (explaining the
forest refugia), temperature change [3–6] and river
dynamics [7–11]. In fact, it is unclear if environmental
stability, or dynamic conditions, have contributed to
the present high biodiversity of the tropical rainfor-
ests. A recent study by Hooghiemstra and Van der
Hammen [12] has shown that the plant diversity of the
Amazon rainforest reached the highest level in the
Miocene or Pliocene, and that excessive present-day
phytodiversity should be regarded as a legacy of the
Tertiary.
The Miocene to Pliocene paleoenvironments of
western Amazonia are not well known. In particular,
the Miocene paleoenvironment has long been a matter
of debate. Recent studies however have demonstrated
that during the Miocene, Western Amazonia was a
tidally influenced sea [13–17]. The transition from
this tidally influenced sea to the modern drainage net-
work has been poorly studied. Some authors (e.g.,
[17,18]) suggest that Andean tectonics may have
caused the closure of this Miocene sea and allowed
the modern Amazon drainage network to develop.
Based on extensive sampling and on the geochem-
istry of Amazonian foreland basin sediments that are
likely to have recorded the erosonial unroofing history
of the orogen, this study is aimed at i) establishing the
provenance of Miocene tidal sediments and of Late
Miocene–Pliocene fluvial sediments of the Western
Amazonian foreland basin, deducing the kinematic
unroofing of the potential source terranes and iii) asses-
sing the potential control of Andean foreland basin
tectonics in the paleo-Amazonian drainage network.

The western Amazonian basin is considered to be
the retroarc foreland basin of the Cenozoic Andes

[19,20]. Recent studies in northern Peru [17,21] have
shown that the northwestern and south Amazonian
foreland basin entered a four-component configuration
(wedge-top, foredeep, forebulge and backbulge depo-
zones; [22]) since the Middle–Late Miocene (15–10
Ma). Forebulge and backbulge depozones constitute
the less subsiding depozones of a foreland basin sys-
tem [22]. Wedge-top and particularly foredeep depo-
zones undergo high subsidence rates and hence are
likely to record a more complete sedimentary filling of
the basin.

The north Amazonian foreland basin (NAFB) can
be divided into four depozones [17,21]: i) the Hual-
laga wedge-top depozone; ii) the Maran˜o´n foredeep
depozone; iii) the Iquitos forebulge depozone; and iv)
the Pevas backbulge depozone (Fig. 1a and b). The
Oriente basin constituted the Ecuadorian part of the
foredeep depozone [23]. The Miocene formations,
which are broadly composed of tidal deposits, have
been sampled all along the NAFB (Figs. 1a and 2): the
Ipururo formation (called hereafter Fm) in the wedge-
top depozone (Huallaga basin, [21]; the Curaray Fm
in the foredeep depozone (Oriente basin, [23], the
Pebas Fm in the forebulge depozone (Iquitos Arch;
[17]) and in the backbulge depozone (Pevas back-
bulge depozone). The transition from marine to con-
tinental sedimentation can be observed in currently
uplifting depozones (i.e., the wedge-top depozone and
the forebulge depozones; Fig. 1b). Provenance in the
wedge-top depozone is rather well constrained and
sediments accumulating in this zone come from the
thrust uplifted structures [22]. On the contrary, sedi-
ments accumulating in the forebulge depozone may
have come from the thrust and fold belt or from the
craton (see [22] for a review). In the Iquitos forebulge
depozone, five depositional units overlying the Pebas
Fm were defined (i.e., the Nauta1 Member (Mb), the
Nauta2 Mb, the White Sand Fm, the Amazon Fm, and
the Quaternary floodplain deposits (QFP); Fig. 2,
[17]). The Nauta1 Mb, estimated to be Late Miocene
in age [24], corresponds to estuarine deposits (Fig. 2).
The Nauta2 Mb consists of fluvial deposits and is
present only in the western part of the forebulge
(Fig. 2). The time-equivalent of Nauta2 Mb is the
White Sand Fm, which is located in the eastern part

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
59

Fig. 1. a) Locations of sampled outcrops. NAFB: North Amazonian foreland basin; SAFB: South Amazonian foreland basin and b) Schematic
cross-section depicting the concept of foreland basin system sensu DeCelles and Giles [22] with the wedge-top, foredeep, forebulge and
backbulge at approximately true scale. Depozone is labeled dz. SAZ: Subandean Zone.

of the forebulge (Fig. 2). The Pliocene fluvial Ama-
zon Fm was deposited over an erosion surface that
eroded all these formations. The Quaternary flood-
plain deposits (QFP) correspond to the floodplain
deposits of the modern Amazon drainage network
(Fig. 2).

The south Amazonian foreland basin (SAFB)
entered a four-component configuration during the
Late Miocene [25,26]. Samples were collected in the
Beni subandean wedge-top depozone, in the Madre de

Dios foredeep depozone and in the forebulge–back-
bulge Beni depozone (Fig. 1a). Due to dating uncer-
tainty, the location of the Miocene forebulge in the
SAFB is not precisely known and for that reason the
forebulge and the backbulge depozones are not sepa-
rated in Fig. 1a and b. The Madre de Dios Fm
corresponds to tidal deposits [15,26] and has been
sampled in the Madre de Dios foredeep depozone
(Madre de Dios basin; Fig. 1a) and in the Beni fore-
bulge–backbulge depozone (Beni-Mamore basin; Fig.
1a). Both uplifted terranes of the Beni subandean zone
and the Brazilian craton have been sampled in order to
provide potential sources for the Amazonian foreland
basin sediments. The Pliocene fluvial sediments of the
Beni forebulge–backbulge depozone (In˜apari Fm
[27]) have also been collected, Fig. 1a). The location,
the estimated age, the average grain size (mud or
sand) and the depositional setting for each sample
are available in Table A1 (depository data). The
collected samples range from muds to fine-grained
sandstones.

104 samples were analyzed by Quadrupole ICP-
MS for trace elements at the LMTG (Toulouse,
France) and 97 of these were selected for major
elements, determined by ICP-AES at the CRPG
(Nancy, France). Individual analyses can be found
in Table A2 (depository data). 30 representative

Madre de Dios Fm
Madre de Dios
Fm

samples were selected for determination of Sc con-
centrations (Chemex Labs, Canada) and for Sr and
Nd isotopic composition.
After crushing, pulverization, and homogeniza-
tion, rock and sediment samples were dissolved in
HF-HNO3 in Teflon beakers. Nd and Sr concentra-
tions were measured by ICP-MS and the values
compared with those obtained by ICP-MS after an
alkaline fusion. The relative differences between the
two sets of values were around 3%, which suggest
that Sr and Nd passed into the solution during the
acid digestion.
Aliquots containing about 1000 ng of Sr and Nd
were loaded into the ion exchange columns. Sr and Nd
were separated using the Sr-SPEC, TRU-SPEC and
LN-SPEC resins (Eichrom). Nd and Sr isotopic ratios
were measured using a Finnigan Mat 261 thermal
ionization mass spectrometer in the dynamic mode.
During the Nd run, the 146Nd/ 144Nd (=0.7219) was
used to correct the signal for mass fractionation. For
each sample, the absence of Sm was checked. The
accuracy of the measurements was checked on the
Rennes University standard for Nd (0.511961F14
calibrated value relative to the La Jolla standard by
the laboratories of Brest, Toulouse and Rennes; see
[28]). During the Sr run, the 86Sr/ 88Sr (=0.1194)
was used to correct the signal for mass fractionation.
The accuracy of the measurements was checked on
the NBS 987 standard for Sr (=0.710240). The
average values were within the range given for
these standards, so that no instrumental bias had to

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
61

be taken into account. The repeatability on these
standards was around 15 ppm. This value was con-
sidered for the overall uncertainty of all measure-
ments,
even
if
the
internal
precision
of
some
individual samples was lower. Total blanks (acid
digestion, column chemistry) for Nd and Sr were
checked by ICP-MS and were found to be negligible
compared to the Nd and Sr amounts loaded on the
columns.
The measured 143Nd/ 144Nd ratios are presented
as fractional deviation in parts per 104 (units) from
143Nd/ 144Nd in a Chondritic Uniform Reservoir
(CHUR)
as
measured
today:
eNd(0)=[(143Nd/
144Nd)S/ICHUR(0)1]*104 where (143Nd/ 144Nd)S is
the ratio measured in the sample today and ICHUR(0) is
the 143Nd/ 144Nd in the CHUR reference reservoir
today (ICHUR(0)=0.512638; [29]).

Details of the major and trace element (including
rare earth elements) geochemistry of the Neogene
Amazonian sediments were discussed in a companion
paper (Roddaz et al., in press). Weathering as well as
sedimentary sorting effects were carefully evaluated
before drawing conclusions on provenance based on
trace element geochemistry. We concluded that weath-
ering and sedimentary sorting have not played a sig-
nificant
role
in
the
chemical
differentiation
of
immobile elements of the NAFB and SAFB sedi-
ments. Therefore, Trace elements such as Th, Sc, Zr,
Hf and REEs as well as elemental ratios such as Th/
Sc and Cr/Th are considered to be valid tools to
determine the provenance of NAFB and SAFB sedi-
ments as it has been demonstrated in other studies (see
[30] for a review).

The concentrations of trace elements (including
REEs) for the 30 selected samples are given in
Table 1. REE patterns for these samples are shown
in Fig. 3. Fig. 4 shows variations of Eu anomaly, Cr/
Th and Th/Sc ratios for each formation. The Zr/Sc
versus Th/Sc diagram (Fig. 5) is used to highlight the
samples which are enriched in zircons due to sedi-
mentary sorting and recycling.

4.1.1. North Amazonian foreland basin
In Fig. 5, only the samples from the Late Miocene
Pliocene White Sand Fm (Iquitos forebulge) follow
the sediment recycling trend suggesting that sedimen-
tary sorting and recycling led to zircon enrichment.
Other NAFB samples plot close to the Upper Con-
tinental Crust (UCC) or along the mantle/crust com-
positional trend indicating that sedimentary recycling
and sorting were minor (Fig. 5).

4.1.1.1. Miocene tidal sediments.
The analyzed
sample of the Ecuadorian foredeep (Curaray Fm)
has low Eu anomaly (Eu/Eu*: 0.84), low Th/Sc
value (~0.42) and high Cr/Th value (~20.9) compared
to Upper Continental Crust (UCC) and to the Post
Archean Australian Shales (PAAS) values (Table 1).
The Zr/Sc ratio is commonly used as a measure of the
degree of sedimentary recycling which leads to the
enrichment of the stable mineral zircon in the deposits
[31]. The Zr/Sc value of the Curaray Fm (~13.6) is
similar to that of the UCC and PAAS indicating that a
recycled sedimentary source was a minor component
(Table 1).
The samples from the wedge-top depozone (Ipur-
uro Fm) have contrasting REE patterns and ratios
(e.g. Eu/Eu*, Th/Sc and Cr/Th). The Th/Sc ratios
(0.87–1.30; average ~1.08) are higher than those of
the other formations with the exception of the White
Sand Fm. Eu anomalies and Cr/Th ratios of the
Ipururo Fm are similar to those of PAAS and UCC
(Fig. 4 and Table 1).
The samples from the Pebas Fm in the Iquitos
forebulge and in the Pevas backbulge have similar
REE patterns (Fig. 3). Their Th/Sc ratios range from
0.68 to 0.90 (average ~0.82) and they have similar Eu
anomalies (0.53–0.76; average ~0.67) and Cr/Th
ratios (3.9–4.8; average ~4.6). The Zr/Sc ratio exhi-
bits two clusters: one higher than UCC and PAAS
(samples POM 37A, POM 54A and POM 007H) and
one lower (samples IQ 13E, POM 54B and POM
007G). Pebas Zr contents are slightly higher than
UCC and PAAS (Table 1).
The Nauta1 Mb has Eu anomalies and Cr/Th
ratios similar to those of the Pebas Fm (Fig. 5)
and to those of PAAS and UCC (Table 2 and Fig.
4).
Compared
with
these
latter
formations,
the
Nauta1 Mb has higher Zr/Sc ratio (~18.6) and
lower Th/Sc value (0.55).

4.1.1.2. Late Miocene Pliocene fluvial sediments.
Compared with the sediments of the Nauta1 Mb, the
samples of the Nauta2 Mb have similar Cr/Th ratios,
higher Eu anomalies and higher Th/Sc values (1.03
and 0.96; Fig. 4). In addition, they are enriched in Zr
Madre de Dios Fm (Madre de Dios foredeep)

relative to PAAS and UCC and have higher Zr/Sc
ratios (Table 1).
The quartz-rich sand of the White Sand Fm (IQ 2)
has REE patterns with similar shapes as PAAS and
other sediments, yet at lower concentrations due to

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
67

Fig. 4. Provenance ratios for NAFB and SAFB sediments. Mean and Maximum/Minimum values for each formation are reported. Eu anomalies
and Cr/Th ratio are based on 104 analyses. Individual Th/Sc ratios are reported in Table 2. SAZ: Subandean Zone; MD: Madre de Dios; B: Beni-
Mamore basin; Iqfb: Iquitos forebulge; Pvbb: Pevas backbulge; UCC: Upper Continental Crust [46]. Basic sediment values from Cullers [50].
Note the high Eu/Eu*, Cr/Th and low Th/Sc ratios for the Curaray Fm and for some sample of the Amazon Fm.

dilution by quartz. Due to overall low trace element
contents that are close to the analytical detection limit,
elemental ratios may not accurately characterize the
source composition. However, together with its asso-
ciated muds, the White Sand sediments have the high-
est Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu* ~0.59 and 0.63), Zr/Sc
ratio (174.6 and 44.7) and Th/Sc ratio (2.6 and 1.3) of
the NAFB.
Some samples from the Amazon Fm have geo-
chemical characteristics similar to those of the Cur-
aray Fm, with low Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu* ~0.90,
0.86 and 0.80) and relatively low Th/Sc (0.41;
0.67; and 0, 69) and high Cr/Th ratios (Cr/Th
~14) compared to UCC and PAAS values (Table 1
and Fig. 4). Other sediments have trace elements
characteristics similar to UCC and PAAS (Table 1
and Fig. 4).
The Quaternary floodplain deposits (QFP), which
represent the floodplain deposits of the Amazon
River, are enriched in Zr (~461 ppm) if compared
with the UCC and PAAS (Table 1) and consequently

South Amazonian foreland basin
North Amazonian foreland basin

have a higher Zr/Sc value (~30.1). This suggests that
sedimentary recycling led to zircon enrichment. Other
chemical ratios are similar to those of the PAAS and
UCC (Table 1 and Fig. 4).

4.1.2. South Amazonian foreland basin
In Fig. 5, three samples (BEN 34, BEN 42A and
TIP 003A) of the Paleozoic–Mesozoic sediments plot
along the sediment recycling trend indicating that they
are enriched in zircon due to sedimentary sorting and
recycling. Other SAFB samples formed a tight group
that plot close to NAFB samples (Fig. 5).

4.1.2.1. Sources.
The potential Paleozoic–Mesozoic
sediment sources of the Neogene SAFB sediments
have contrasting REE patterns and Eu anomalies
(0.36 (TIP 003A, Silurian)–0.95 (TIP 002, Ordovi-
cian), average ~0.68), Zr/Sc ratios (5.2 (TIP 004,
Silurian)–450.1 (TIP003A), average ~115.5), Th/Sc
ratios (0.59 (TIP 004)–6.62 (TIP 003A), average
~2.23) and low Cr/Th ratio (0.8 (TIP 003A)–8 (TIP

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
68

Miocene tidal formations
Late Miocene Pliocene fluvial formations

Fig. 5. Plot of Th/Sc versus Zr/Sc for Neogene Amazonian foreland basin sediments. Sediments which plot along the mantle/crust
compositional trend indicates have their variations in Th/Sc and Zr/Sc ratios due to compositional variations of the provenance. Sediments
that follow the sediment recycling trend are enriched in heavy mineral, especially in zircon due to sedimentary sorting and recycling. Trends
after [30].

004). Samples BEN 42A (Tertiary) and TIP 002
(Ordovician) have low Eu anomalies (~0.84 and
~0.95, respectively) but other ratios such as Zr/Sc
(~13.6 and ~19.1), Th/Sc (~1.8 and ~0.9) and Cr/Th
(~4.6 and ~6.2) are indicative of felsic/sedimentary
recycling.

4.1.2.2. Sediments.
The samples of the SAFB fore-
deep (Madre de Dios Fm in the Madre de Dios fore-
deep) have REE patterns, Eu anomalies and Zr and Sc
contents similar to PAAS (Figs. 3 and 4 and Table 1).
The analyzed samples have low Zr/Sc ratios (8.4–9.3,
average ~8.8) suggesting that sedimentary recycling
was minor.
Compared with the latter sediments, the sample of
the SAFB forebulge–backbulge depozones (Madre de
Dios Fm in the Beni-Mamore basin) has higher Zr/Sc
Madre de Dios Fm (Madre de Dios foredeep)

ratios (23.9), Th/Sc ratios (1.03) and lower Cr/Th
ratios (4.5). This suggests that these sediments have
received input of more evolved/felsic detritus or
recycled sediments.
The Late Miocene–Pliocene sediments of the
SAFB forebulge backbulge depozone (In˜apari Fm)
have similar trace elements pattern as those from the
Miocene
SAFB
forebulge–backbulge
depozone
(Table 1 and Fig. 4).

The Sr and Nd concentrations and isotopic compo-
sitions of the analyzed Neogene Western Amazonian
sediments are given in Table 2. Temporal and geogra-
phical variations of isotopic compositions are shown
in Fig. 6.

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
69

Nd–Sr isotopic systematics of the analyzed sediments; NAFB: North Amazonian foreland basin; SAFB: South Amazonian foreland basin

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
70
Fig. 6. Stratigraphic variations of qNd(0) and 87Sr/ 86Sr values for the analyzed Neogene Amazonian foreland basin sediments.

4.2.1. North Amazonian foreland basin
The sediments from the NAFB have a broad range
of eNd(0) values (ranging from 3.2 to 15.5) with a
comparatively narrow range of 87Sr/ 86Sr composition
(0.709335–0.724371; Table 2 and Fig. 6).

4.2.1.1. Miocene tidal sediments.
The Ecuadorian
foredeep sample (Curaray Fm) has the highest eNd(0)
value (3.2) with a 87Sr/ 86Sr composition of 0.71324.
The samples from the wedge-top depozone (Ipururo
Fm) have lower eNd(0) values (8.3 to 9.5) with
87Sr/ 86Sr composition ranging from 0.70934 to
0.71687. The samples from the Pebas Fm both in the
Iquitos forebulge and in the Pevas backbulge have
similar isotopic characteristics. They display two sets
of eNd(0) values: one similar to that of the Ipururo Fm
(8.4 to 9.4) and the other lower (10.5 to 11.9).
They have a narrow range of 87Sr/ 86Sr compositions
(0.71557–0.71773). The sample from the Nauta1 Mb
(Iquitos forebulge) has an eNd(0) value (~9.6) similar
to that of the Ipururo Fm, but a slightly higher 87Sr/ 86Sr
composition (~0.72325).

4.2.1.2. Late Miocene Pliocene fluvial sediments.
The samples from the Nauta2 Mb have contrasted
eNd(0) values (8.4 and 11.4) with comparatively
high 87Sr/ 86Sr compositions (0.72050–0.72437). The
mud sample from the White Sand Fm has higher

eNd(0) value (10.8) than its associated sand (15.5)
and lower
87Sr/ 86Sr compositions (0.71332 and
0.71836, respectively). The samples of the Amazon
Fm display two sets of eNd(0) values: one similar
to that of the Ipururo Fm (8.5) and the other
similar to that of the Curaray Fm (4 to 5.2).
In contrast, they have similar
87Sr/ 86Sr composi-
tions (0.71054–0.71281). The QFP sample has low
eNd(0) value (10.9), with high 87Sr/ 86Sr compo-
sition (0.72427).

4.2.2.1. Sources.
The samples from the Subandean
Zone (SAZ) have eNd(0) values ranging from 9.3 to
14.1 with
87Sr/ 86Sr composition ranging from
0.72028 to 0.75074. The Brazilian craton granite
sample has low eNd(0) value (11.7), with high
87Sr/ 86Sr composition (0.893764).

4.2.2.2. Sediments.
Compared with the NAFB sedi-
ments, the SAFB sediments have a narrower range of
eNd(0)
values
(10.4
to
12.7)
with
higher
87Sr/ 86Sr compositions (0.728347 to 0.744547). The
samples of the SAFB foredeep depozone (Madre de
Dios Fm in the Madre de Dios foredeep) have low
eNd(0) values (10.4 and 11.2) with
87Sr/ 86Sr
compositions of 0.72835 and 0.73454. Compared

71

with the samples from the latter depozone, the sample
of the SAFB forebulge–backbulge depozones (Madre
de Dios Fm in the Beni-Mamore basin) has lower
eNd(0) value (12.7), with higher 87Sr/ 86Sr compo-
sition (0.74111). The Late Miocene–Pliocene sedi-
ments of the SAFB forebulge–backbulge depozones
(In˜apari Fm) have eNd(0) values from 11.5 to

Sediments of the SAFB have trace elements char-
acteristics close to those of PAAS and UCC (Figs. 3
and 4 and Table 1). One can observe a slight differ-

ence between the samples from the foredeep depozone

and those from the forebulge–backbulge depozones
(Madre de Dios Fm in the Beni-Mamore basin and

have typical UCC Zr/Sc values whereas the samples
from the former one have slightly lower Zr/Sc ratios.
In addition, the sediments from the forebulge–back-
bulge depozones have higher Th/Sc, Zr/Sc and lower
Cr/Th ratios than those from the foredeep depozone
(Figs. 3 and 4 and Table 1). In the eNd(0) versus Th/
Sc diagram (Fig. 7), these samples show a co-varia-
tion of eNd(0) with Th/Sc, consistent with dilution
from young arc material. The sediments from the
forebulge–backbulge depozones are more felsic than
those from the foredeep depozone (Fig. 7).

Madre de Dios Fm (Madre de Dios foredeep)

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
72

diagram (Fig. 8). The isotopic data of these samples
are compared with several other relevant source fields
in this diagram: Mesozoic and Neogene volcanic
rocks [32,33]; Neogene Ecuadorian basaltic lavas
[34]; Central Depression rocks, Altiplano rocks,
Oriental Cordillera and Subandean zone sediment
domains [35]; modern suspended sediments from dif-
ferent Amazonian rivers and Amazon river mouth
[36,37]; French Guiana shelf sediments [37]; type I
and type II Amazonian foreland basin sands [38].
These two types of sand have been defined by the
authors [38] as bthe mechanical mixtures of three
components: the Andean volcanic rocks of two dis-
tinctly different suites and the Brazilian Shield derived
metasedimentsQ. Type I sands have a more positive
eNd(0) values than Type II sands [38].
Overall, Amazonian foreland basin sediments in
conjunction with the Andean magmatic trend and

Miocene tidal formations
Late Miocene Pliocene fluvial formations

Andean sediments [35] define a hyperbolic relation-
ship similar to that observed by Basu et al. [38] for
SAFB sands, with one endmember being the primitive
Arc and the other the upper continental crust of the
Brazilian shield (Fig. 8). In Fig. 8, the sediments of
the foredeep depozone fall within the field of the
Subandean Zone sediments of Pinto [35] whereas
two samples of the forebulge–backbulge depozones
are out of this field and plot closer to the Brazilian
shield composition. This could suggest that the con-
tribution of the Brazilian shield is greater in the fore-
bulge–backbulge depozones than in the Madre de
Dios foredeep depozone. Alternatively, the Silurian
sample (TIP 004) that presents a high radiogenic
strontium isotopic composition (~0.750739) could
be a potential source for 87Sr/ 86Sr enrichment of the
forebulge–backbulge sediments. However, in the
northern Bolivian Oriental Cordillera and subandean

Mesozoic volcanic rocks
Neogene volcanic rocks
Central Depression
Altiplano
Oriental Cordillera
Subandean Zone
Madre de Dios Fm (Madre de Dios foredeep)

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
73

zone, Silurian rocks are involved in thrust fault-pro-
pagation anticlines [39] and are unlikely to have been
the only rocks to be unroofed. Other terrains of the
Eastern Cordillera and of the Subandean Zone that
have been unroofed at approximately the same time,
plot nearer to the Andean Arc trend (Fig. 8). Since the
sampled outcrops of the forebulge–backbulge depo-
zones are situated at least at 300 km from Eastern
Cordillera and the Subandean Zone, the samples, if
derived from these areas should reflect mixing of
these latter sources with Silurian rocks, which would
have lowered the 87Sr/ 86Sr isotopic compositions. In
addition, if the Silurian rocks were at the origin of the
enrichment in 87Sr/ 86Sr isotopic compositions of the
sediments of the forebulge–backbulge depozones, the
sediments from the foredeep depozone, geographi-
cally closer to the Subandean Zone and Eastern Cor-
dillera than the sediments from forebulge–backbulge
depozones, should have recorded a relative enrich-
ment in 87Sr/ 86Sr isotopic composition and the trend
defined in Fig. 8 should be reversed. Therefore, a
greater contribution of cratonic rocks is more plausi-
ble than a Silurian source to explain that 87Sr/ 86Sr
isotopic compositions are higher in the forebulge–
backbulge depozones than in the foredeep depozone.

In order to check for source variations during the
Neogene, tidal Miocene sediments are separated
from Late Miocene–Pliocene fluvial deposits. The
Miocene tidal sediments of the NAFB have been
sampled
in
all
the
foreland
basin
depozones
whereas
the
Late
Miocene–Pliocene
sediments
have been sampled only in the present-day fore-
bulge depozone.

5.2.1. Miocene tidal sediments
The Curaray Fm, which recorded the erosion of the
Ecuadorian Andes, has geochemical characteristics of
basic/andesitic source derived sediment with high Cr/
Th, low Th/Sc and low Eu anomaly (Figs. 3 and 4,
and Table 1). Its eNd(0) value is the lowest of all the
analyzed sediments (3.18). In Fig. 8, the Curaray
sample plots close to the Central Depression, the
Neogene volcanic rocks and Ecuadorian basaltic
lavas fields. This suggests that the Curaray Fm is
mainly derived from arc andesitic rocks as Central

Depression rocks have been shown to be derived from
andesitic to rhyodacitic sources [40].
The other formations (e.g. Ipururo Fm, Pebas Fm,
and Nauta1 Mb) have trace element characteristics
close to those of UCC and PAAS (Figs. 3 and 4,
and Table 1). In Fig. 8, these formations plot within
the Altiplano field and close to Bolivian sand isotopic
compositions of Basu et al. [38] and hence are likely
to have an Andean provenance. Two samples of the
Ipururo Fm plot outside the sands field of Basu et al.
[38]. These samples have high CaO content due to the
presence of carbonates, which could have lowered the
bulk 87Sr/ 86Sr isotopic composition.

5.2.2. Late Miocene–Pliocene fluvial sediments
The Nauta2 Mb has chemical characteristics simi-
lar to those of UCC and PAAS (Figs. 3 and 4, and
Table 1). In Fig. 7, the Nauta2 Mb samples are close
to the composition of the upper crust and in Fig. 8,
they plot within the Oriental Cordillera field sedi-
ments and close to the isotopic compositions of the
modern Amazon Mouth [37]. The Nauta2 Mb sedi-
ments were deposited by an Andean Late Miocene–
Pliocene drainage network that could represent the
bLate Miocene–Pliocene Paleo-AmazonQ.
The sand of the White Sand Fm is almost exclu-
sively composed of quartz (SiO2 ~99.6 wt.%).
Together with their associated muds, these have
high Zr/Sc, high Th/Sc and high Eu anomalies.
These characteristics suggest a felsic and/or recycled
sedimentary source for these deposits. In Fig. 7, the
same trend appears and the sand sample falls outside
of the field of the Amazonian foreland basin sedi-
ments because of its low eNd(0) value (15.5).
Quaternary quartz-rich sands are ubiquitous in Ama-
zonia [41–43]. The enrichment in quartz is ascribed
to reworking of either Tertiary foreland basin depos-
its or cratonic sediments/gneisses or extreme in situ
tropical weathering. From field evidence, the White
Sand Fm deposited in the eastern bcratonicQ part and
the Nauta2 Mb deposited at the same time in the
western bAndeanQ part of the Iquitos forebulge [17].
If extreme tropical weathering was the cause of the
quartz enrichment, it would have affected in a simi-
lar way both the White Sand Fm and the Nauta2 Mb
that are geographically close. The Nauta2 Mb is
Andean in provenance and does not show such
enrichment in quartz. Therefore, it is likely that the

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
74

White Sand Fm had a different source than the
Nauta2 Mb. Moreover, the base of the White Sand
Fm is made up of quartz clasts up to 10 cm long
[17] and the White Sand Fm is located only in the
eastern part of the Iquitos forebulge [17,44]. This
strongly suggests that the White Sand Fm was
deposited by an eastern fluvial system draining the
craton. The low eNd(0) value of the sand (15.5)
supports this interpretation.
Two samples of the Amazon Fm (POM 002B and
POM 003D) have chemical and isotopic characteristics
of basic/andesitic source derived sediments similar to
those of the Curaray sample (Tables 1 and 2) suggesting
that they are derived from the same sources (Figs. 3, 4,
7 and 8). The last sample of the Amazon Fm (POM
55A) plots close to those of the Ipururo Fm confirming
its Andean origin (Figs. 7 and 8).
The Quaternary bmodernQ floodplain deposits are
silts and therefore closely represent the source com-
position [45]. These have Eu anomalies, Cr/Th and
Th/Sc similar to PAAS and UCC (Table 1), and are
likely to be derived from typical fractionated felsic
upper crust [46]. In Fig. 8, the QFP sample plots close
to the Amazon Mouth [37] and lies within the Sub-
andean Zone rocks field. These observations confirm
that the sediments from the Amazon River have their
isotopic compositions mainly inherited from Andean
rocks.

5.3. Insights into the drainage and tectonic history of
Western Amazonia

This study based on major and trace element
geochemistry and Nd–Sr isotopic systematics of
NAFB and SAFB sediments shows that the SAFB
sediments are more felsic in composition than the
NAFB sediments. In addition, the NAFB sediments
display three distinct isotopic signatures: i) an old
upper
crust
signature
with
low
eNd(0)
values
(between 10.5 and 11.9) that is only present
in the Iquitos forebulge and in the Pevas backbulge
and
slightly
higher
eNd(0)
values
that
cluster
between 8 and 9.6 and are present in the Hual-
laga basin (Peruvian Subandean Zone, Fig. 1a), the
Iquitos forebulge and Pevas backbulge; ii) a strong
negative eNd(0) value (15.5) in sands of the
White Sand Fm, which bears evidence of a cratonic
drainage network; and iii) a younger arc andesitic

rock signature found in the Miocene syn-orogenic
sediments of Ecuador (Curaray Fm) and the Late
Miocene–Pliocene sediments of the Amazon Fm in
the Iquitos forebulge depozone.
The Neogene evolution of Western Amazonia is
somewhat controversial in particular because of the
lack of geological/geochemical data on such a large
basin scale. Nevertheless, recent studies demon-
strated that the Western Amazonian foreland basin
has experienced long-term tidal sedimentation during
the Late Miocene [13–17,24]. For this reason, we
believe that sediments we have studied are represen-
tative of the erosion of Andean/cratonic watersheds.
Our data indicate that the Ecuadorian Andes deliv-
ered greater quantity of basic/andesitic detritus to the
Amazonian foreland basin than the Bolivian and
Peruvian Andes. However, this basic/andesitic detri-
tus got trapped in the Ecuadorian Oriente foredeep
and did not reach the Iquitos forebulge as shown by
the absence of basic/andesitic derived sediments in
the Miocene deposits on both sides of the forebulge
(Iquitos forebulge and backbulge depozones). Our
data in the SAFB confirm results of Basu et al.
[38] who suggested that sands from the Madre de
Dios basin were mainly derived from Andean Paleo-
zoic/Mesozoic sedimentary rocks ultimately derived
from the Brazilian shield. Our results also give evi-
dence of increasing Brazilian shield contributions
toward the East.
The transition from this Miocene tide-influenced
sea, also called bPebas systemQ [47], to the modern
transcontinental Amazon River is poorly known
although Hoorn et al. [18] suggested that uplift of
the Colombian Cordillera caused the closure of the
Amazon–Carribean connections.
The Iquitos forebulge is a key area as it is the place
where the Maran˜o´n River joins the Ucayali River to
form the Amazon River. Sixty-five kilometers east-
wards, the Rio Napo (the largest river draining the
Ecuadorian Andes) joins the Amazon River. The
development of several Neogene formations that out-
crop in the Iquitos forebulge (Fig. 2) was controlled
by the forebulge uplift [17]. Based on our geochem-
ical results and on our field studies [17], we propose a
schematic evolution of the Neogene Amazon drainage
basin (Fig. 9).
During the Middle–Late Miocene (Fig. 9a), the
NAFB was covered by the Pebas tide-influenced sea

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
75

Fig. 9. Schematic Neogene evolution of the NAFB: a) Late Miocene configuration with the tide-influenced Pebas sea covering the NAFB. Note
that the Iquitos Arch was emerged, b) Late Miocene–Pliocene configuration: the NAFB became emerged due to an increase in the Andean
uplifts. As a consequence the Iquitos forebulge uplifted and created two drainage networks, the western Andean drainage (Nauta2 Mb), and the
eastern cratonic drainage network (White Sand Fm). The uplift of the Ecuadorian Andes was recorded by the sediments of the Amazon Fm, c)
Present-day configuration of the Western Amazonian basin with Ucayali and Maran˜o´n rivers merging in the Iquitos forebulge to form the
Amazon River.

[13,17,21,24]. At that time, the Ecuadorian Oriente
basin and the Peruvian Huallaga basin formed the
foredeep depozone (i.e., the most subsiding depo-
zone; [22]) of the NAFB [21,23]. Sediments from
these basins have a distinct provenance: the sediment

of the Oriente basin has a strong basic/andesitic
signature not shown by the sediments of the Hual-
laga basin and did not arrive to the Iquitos forebulge
depozone. At approximately the same time, however,
the sediments from the Pebas Fm were Andean in

M. Roddaz et al. / Earth and Planetary Science Letters 239 (2005) 57–78
76

origin both in the Iquitos forebulge and in the Pevas
backbulge.
Since the Late Miocene, Andean uplift proceeded
in phases culminating in a period of most rapid uplift
in the Plio–Pleistocene [48,49]. In the Amazonian
foreland basin, sedimentation became continental.
The geochemical signatures of Late Miocene–Plio-
cene continental sediments indicate that the Iquitos
high acted as a drainage divide between transverse
rivers issued from the Andes (Nauta2 Mb) and rivers
issued from the eastern craton (White Sand Fm; Fig.
9b). This pattern is interpreted as the result of the
flexural uplift of the Iquitos forebulge in response to
thrust-induced tectonic loading of the Eastern Cor-
dillera and Subandean Zone [17]. The amount of
sediment derived from basic/andesitic rocks in the
Paleo-Amazon River near the Iquitos forebulge also
supports this interpretation. It is suggested that over-
filling of the foreland basin associated with regional
increase in slope and a stage of relative tectonic
quiescence was responsible for burying of the fore-
bulge outpaced by elongating transverse major rivers
issued from the Andes (Maran˜on/Ucayali, Napo; Fig.
9c) thus creating the present-day drainage network
(Fig. 9c).
Several conclusions can be drawn from this study:

1) Neogene sediments of Western Amazonia are
derived from a mixture of Andean volcanic rocks
and cratonic shields rocks (Figs. 7 and 8);
2) Neogene sediments of southwestern Amazonia are
the product of long-term weathering, recycling and
erosion of the Brazilian shield and Paleozoic and
Mesozoic Andean terrains. Eastwards, these sedi-
ments show enrichment in a first-cycle Brazilian
shield component;
3) The Ecuadorian Andes supplied most of the basic/
andesitic detritus to the northern Amazonian fore-
land basin. During the Miocene, these sediments
were trapped in the Ecuadorian foredeep. Pliocene
uplift of the Andes has caused the emergence and
erosion of the Ecuadorian foredeep and transport of
these basic/andesitic sediments to the transconti-
nental Amazon River;

4) In the distal part of the NAFB, the successive
uplifts of the Iquitos forebulge were responsible
for Late Miocene to Pliocene divide between
Andean and cratonic drainage systems. The mod-
ern bAmazon RiverQ drainage network is no
younger than the Pliocene.
